summary: This is a memorandum opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding a protective order in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The court adopts the government's proposed protective order, restricting Maxwell from publicly referencing alleged victims or witnesses except those who have publicly identified themselves in this litigation, and denies Maxwell's request to restrict potential government witnesses from using discovery materials for purposes other than trial preparation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, seeking modifications to a protective order regarding disclosure of alleged victims' and witnesses' identities.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge issuing the memorandum opinion and order, ruling on the protective order dispute.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as a central figure in the case; public statements about him are discussed in the context of witness privacy.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant in a case relating to Jeffrey Epstein; the protective order discusses public statements about both individuals.

events.title: Court Issues Protective Order Ruling
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues a memorandum opinion and order adopting the government's proposed protective order in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell.

keyFacts: The court adopted the government's proposed protective order, restricting Ghislaine Maxwell from publicly referencing alleged victims or witnesses except those who have publicly identified themselves in this litigation.
The court found the government showed good cause to protect the privacy of alleged victims and witnesses, even if they had made past public statements about Maxwell or Epstein.

The court denied Maxwell's request to restrict potential government witnesses and their counsel from using discovery materials for purposes other than preparing for trial, calling the request 'unprecedented'.
The ruling resolves a dispute between the defense and prosecution over the scope of the protective order in Maxwell's criminal case.
